name: two
content:
two

number
 
 
/tuː/
 
/tuː/
Idioms
jump to other results
  1. ​2
    • There are only two cookies left.
    • two of Sweden’s top financial experts
    • Ten people were invited but only two turned up.
    • Can you lend me two dollars?
    • a two-month contract
    • Look at page two.
    • Two and seven is nine.
    • Three twos are six.
    • I can't read your writing—is this meant to be a two?
    • The bulbs are planted in twos or threes (= groups of two or three).
    • We moved to America when I was two (= two years old).
    • Shall we meet at two (= at two o'clock), then?

    • two
    Word OriginOld English twā (feminine and neuter) of Germanic origin; related to Dutch twee and German zwei, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin and Greek duo. Compare with twain.
Idioms
be in two minds about something/about doing something (British English)
(North American English be of two minds about something/about doing something)
  1. ​to be unable to decide what you think about somebody/something, or whether to do something or not
    • I was in two minds about the book (= I didn't know if I liked it or not).
    • She's in two minds about accepting his invitation.
a day, moment, pound, etc. or two
 
  1. ​one or a few days, moments, pounds, etc.
    • May I borrow it for a day or two?
fall between two stools
  1. ​(British English) to fail to be or to get either of two choices, both of which would have been acceptableTopics Difficulty and failurec2
in two
  1. ​in or into two pieces or halves
    • He broke the bar of chocolate in two and gave me half.
in twos and threes
  1. ​two or three at a time; in small numbers
    • People arrived in twos and threes.
in two shakes | in a couple of shakes
  1. ​(informal) very soon
    • We’ll be there in a couple of shakes.
it takes two to do something
  1. ​(saying) one person cannot be completely responsible for something
    • You can't put all the blame on him. It takes two to make a marriage.
it takes two to tango
  1. ​(informal) used to say that two people or groups, and not just one, are responsible for something that has happened (usually something bad)
not have two cents, pennies, brain cells, etc. to rub together
  1. ​(informal) to be very poor, stupid, etc.
put two and two together
  1. ​to guess the truth from what you see, hear, etc.
    • He's inclined to put two and two together and make five (= reaches the wrong conclusion from what he sees, hears, etc.).
    Topics Doubt, guessing and certaintyc2
that makes two of us
  1. ​(informal) I am in the same position or I agree with you
    • ‘I'm tired!’ ‘That makes two of us!’
    Topics Opinion and argumentc2
two/ten a penny (British English)
(North American English a dime a dozen)
  1. ​very common and therefore not valuable
    • Teachers of history are ten a penny.
two sides of the same coin
  1. ​used to talk about two ways of looking at the same situation
See two in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee two in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: two

name: BBC Two
content:
BBC Two

 
/ˌbiː biː siː ˈtuː/
 
/ˌbiː biː siː ˈtuː/
jump to other results
  1. ​the second television channel of the BBC. Some of its programmes are more serious than those of BBC One.

name: two-bit
content:
two-bit

adjective
 
/ˈtuː bɪt/
 
/ˈtuː bɪt/
[only before noun] (especially North American English, informal)
jump to other results
  1. ​not good or important
    • She wanted to be more than just a two-bit secretary.
See two-bit in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

jump to other results

name: two-four
content:
two-four

noun
 
/ˌtuː ˈfɔː(r)/
 
/ˌtuː ˈfɔːr/
(Canadian English, informal)
jump to other results
  1. ​a case holding 24 cans or bottles of beer
    • A two-four of beer sat on the bench beside them.
See two-four in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: two-ply
content:
two-ply

adjective
 
/ˈtuː plaɪ/
 
/ˈtuː plaɪ/
jump to other results
  1. ​(of wool, cloth, paper or other material) with two threads or layers

name: two-star
content:
two-star

adjective
 
/ˈtuː stɑː(r)/
 
/ˈtuː stɑːr/
[usually before noun]
jump to other results
  1. ​having two stars in a system that measures quality. The highest standard is usually represented by four or five stars
    • a two-star hotel
  2. ​(in the US) having the fourth-highest military rank, and wearing uniform that has two stars on it
See two-star in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: two-star

name: two-step
content:
two-step

noun
 
/ˈtuː step/
 
/ˈtuː step/
jump to other results
  1. ​a dance with long, sliding steps; the music for this dance
Check pronunciation: two-step
matches: one step forward, two steps back
relatives: one step forward, two steps back
one step forward, two steps back

name: two-time
content:
two-time

verb
 
/ˈtuː taɪm/
 
/ˈtuː taɪm/
(informal)
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they two-time
 
/ˈtuː taɪm/
 
/ˈtuː taɪm/
he / she / it two-times
 
/ˈtuː taɪmz/
 
/ˈtuː taɪmz/
past simple two-timed
 
/ˈtuː taɪmd/
 
/ˈtuː taɪmd/
past participle two-timed
 
/ˈtuː taɪmd/
 
/ˈtuː taɪmd/
-ing form two-timing
 
/ˈtuː taɪmɪŋ/
 
/ˈtuː taɪmɪŋ/
jump to other results
  1. ​two-time somebody to not be faithful to a person you have a relationship with, especially a sexual one, by having a secret relationship with somebody else at the same time
    • Are you sure he's not two-timing you?
See two-time in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
